field.label: Application ID
field.comment: You can find your Application ID and API keys in the Algolia dashboard.

field.label: Search-only (public) API key
field.comment: You can find your Application ID and API keys in the Algolia dashboard.

field.label: Admin API key
field.comment: You can find your Application ID and API keys in the Algolia dashboard.

field.label: Index Name Prefix
field.comment: Specify different index prefixes for each environment (eg. local, staging, production). It will prevent your data from being overridden.

field.label: Enable Indexing
field.comment:
Do you want the Algolia extension to push your data to Algolia?
The benefit here is that Algolia will manage to keep your data up to date. If you choose "No", you will need to push and manage your data in a different way.

field.label: Enable Search
field.comment:
Do you want to use Algolia for search?
If not, Magento will perform all searches and not touch Algolia at all.

field.label: Enable Logging
field.comment: Logging generates a significant amount of data and can affect performance of the extension. Use it only for debugging.

field.label: Enable Autocomplete Menu
field.comment:
Do you want to display a search-as-you-type drop-down menu?
It requires your theme to expose a top.search and content block.

field.label: Number of products
field.comment:
How many products do you want to display in the autocomplete menu? Default value is 6.
Set 0 to disable the products section.

field.label: Number of categories
field.comment:
How many categories do you want to display in the autocomplete menu? Default value is 2.
Set 0 to disable the categories section.

field.label: Number of queries
field.comment:
How many query suggestions do you want to display in the autocomplete menu? By default it's disabled.
Set 0 to disable the query suggestion section.

field.label: Minimal query popularity
field.comment: The minimal number of times a query has been performed in order to be suggested in the autocomplete menu. Default value is 1000.

field.label: Minimal number of results per query
field.comment: The minimal number of results a query needs in order to be suggested. Default value is 2.

field.label: Additional Sections
field.comment:
Specify additional sections you want to include in the autocomplete menu (eg. pages, colors, manufacturers).
⚠ All attributes used here have to be configured as facets in the Instant Search Results Page Configuration panel.

field.label: Excluded Pages
field.comment:
Specify pages you don't want to search in.
Pages' indexing documentation: https://www.algolia.com/doc/integration/magento-2/how-it-works/indexing/#pages-indexing
⚠ Do not forget to reindex the Algolia Search Pages indexer after you've modified this panel.

field.label: Render template directives
field.comment:
Do you want to have CMS pages' templates' content (e.g. {{block type="core/template" ...}}) indexed?
⚠ Do not forget to reindex the Algolia Search Pages indexer after you've modified this setting.

field.label: Enable autocomplete menu's debug mode
field.comment: When set to "Yes", the autocomplete menu won't disappear when clicked outside of the menu. It's useful when you debug or style a look and feel of the autocomplete menu.

field.label: Enable Instant Search Results Page
field.comment:
Do you want the products inside a search results page to be searchable and updated with as-you-type experience?
It requires your theme to expose a top.search and content block.
⚠ Enabling instant search results page can potentially break your design and some work will be required to have a good integration with your theme.

field.label: Enable Backend Facet Rendering
field.comment: If you don't want to use Instant Search, you can still activate the Algolia's facet backend rendering. Magento native facets behaviour will be replaced by the extension according to the configuration you define below.

field.label: DOM Selector
field.comment: DOM selector of block in which the search results page will be displayed using JavaScript.

field.label: Number of products per page
field.comment: The number of products displayed on the instant search results page. Default value is 9.

field.label: Facets
field.comment:
Specify the filtering options you want to offer on a search results page.
  - Disjunctive allows a selection of different values per facet (e.g. hotels with 4 OR 5 stars).
  - Conjunctive allows a selection of only one value per facet (e.g. only "Size M").

Set facet as searchable if you want your customers to be able to search for facet values. It's handy when a facet has a lot of values.

Create a Query rule for a facet when you want Algolia to automatically filter on a facet when a user searches for its value in a query. For example, when you create a Query rule for a "color" facet and a user is searching "red shorts", Algolia will internally filter results for the color "red" and search only "shorts". It leads to more relevant results. This query rule is applied for both autocomplete and instant search results.

Find out more about Facets in documentation.

field.label: Number of values per facet
field.comment: The number of values each facet can display. Default value is 10.

field.label: Sorts
field.comment:
Specify different sorting options you want to offer on a search results page.
Each sort will significantly increase the number of records you store in Algolia.
Read more in documentation.

field.label: Replace categories page
field.comment: Do you want to replace default Magento category pages (PLPs) by an instant search results page?

field.label: Show query suggestions when no results
field.comment: Do you want to display the most popular query suggestions on instant search results page when there are no results?

field.label: Add to Cart
field.comment: Do you want to display an "Add To Cart" button in a product on an instant search results page?

field.label: Enable Infinite Scrolling?
field.comment: Do you want to display a "Show More" button to load more results instead of using traditional pagination?

field.label: Attributes
field.comment:
Specify a product's attributes your users can search on (searchable) and the ones required to display search results. The order of the searchable attributes matters: a query matching the first searchable attribute of a product will put this product before the others in the results.

Searchable attributes' documentation: Products' searchable attributes
⚠ Do not forget to reindex the Algolia Search Products indexer after you've modified this panel.

field.label: Ranking
field.comment:
Configure attributes for Custom Ranking - for example, an attribute that reflects popularity of a product (eg. stock status, number of sales).
⚠ Do not forget to reindex the Algolia Search Products indexer after you've modified this panel.

field.label: Replace default image by matching variation
field.comment:
When a customer searches for a "blue dress", Algolia will display the image associated with the blue variation instead of the default picture. The same happens when a customer refines products by any color.

If a customer searches for "blue dress" and refines by "red" color, Algolia will display images for the red (refined) color.

field.label: Index out of stock options for configurable products
Attributes
field.comment:
Specify a category's attributes your users can search on (searchable). The order of the searchable attributes matters: a query matching the first searchable attribute of a category will put this category before the others in the results.

Searchable attributes' documentation: Categories's searchable attributes
⚠ Do not forget to reindex the Algolia Search Categories indexer after you've modified this panel.

field.label: Ranking
field.comment:
Configure attributes for Custom Ranking - for example, an attribute that reflects popularity of a category (eg. products count, total number of sales of the category).
⚠ Do not forget to reindex the Algolia Search Categories indexer after you've modified this panel.

field.label: Show categories not included in navigation
field.comment: Do you want to display all categories in both the autocomplete menu and instant search results page ignoring the "Include in navigation menu" setting?

field.label: Index empty categories?
field.comment: Do you want to display all categories in both the autocomplete menu and instant search results page ignoring if they contain products or not?

field.label: Height
field.comment:
You can specify the size of the images used on the instant search results page.
If your images are already present in some size, eg. 265x265, Algolia's index job may not have to resize those, potentially saving time and resources.

field.label: Type
field.comment: What type of image do you want to display on the instant search results page.

field.label: Enable Indexing Queue
field.comment:
If enabled, all indexing operations (add, remove & update operations) will be done asynchronously using the CRON mechanism.

To schedule the run you need to add this in your crontab:
*/5 * * * * php /absolute/path/to/magento/bin/magento indexer:reindex algolia_queue_runner
⚠ Enabling this option is recommended in production or if your store has a lot of products.

field.label: Number of jobs to run each time the cron is run
field.comment:
Number of queued jobs to run each time the cron is launched. Default value is 5.
⚠ Each time the cron runs it will process ("Max number of element per indexing job" * "Number of jobs to run each time the cron is run") products.

field.label: Number of times to retry processing of queued jobs
Enable Synonyms Management
field.comment: Do you want to manage synonyms in Magento? If not, synonyms will be managed only in Algolia's dashboard and won't be overridden by Magento.

field.label: Synonyms
field.comment:
Synonyms can be defined by a comma-separated list of words that will be considered equivalent by the Algolia engine.
For instance: tv, television, tv set
Using that set, if a record contains “television” and a user searches for “TV”, this record will be returned.

field.label: One-way Synonyms
field.comment:
One-way synonyms allow you to define alternative words for a search term, which are not synonyms to each other.
Let’s take an example: when a user searches for “tablet”, you want him to be able to find iPads and Galaxy Note tablets alike, but you might not want Android tablets to show up when he searches for “iPad”.
To do this, you’d define a one-way synonym set between tablet (as input) and ipad, galaxy note (as synonyms). When the user types in “tablet”, records containing “iPad” and “Galaxy Note” will be returned. However records containing only “tablet” or “Galaxy Note” won’t be returned if he searches for “iPad”.

Algolia offers more synonymys’ types - placeholders and alternative corrections. These types can be managed directly from your Algolia’s dashboard. Any changes you make to placeholders and alternative corrections in Algolia’s dashboard won’t be overridden.

field.label: Synonyms File
field.comment:
If you have a large amount of synonyms (more than 1 hundred), you don't have to manually enter them in the inputs above. You can upload a JSON file with synonyms instead.
⚠ When you upload a JSON file, all the synonyms settings from above will be ignored and only synonyms from the JSON file will be pushed to Algolia.

field.label: DOM selector of a result container on the instant search page
field.comment: The element must contain attributes data-objectid, data-indexname, data-position, and data-queryid.

field.label: Conversion Analytics mode
field.comment: Conversion is tracked when a product was found and clicked in search results and then added to cart / ordered.

field.label: DOM selector of "Add to Cart" buttons
field.comment:
The element has to contain attribute data-objectid or a productId variable needs to be specified in a "frontend" algoliaConfig variable.

More selectors separated by comma (,).

field.label: Delay (in milliseconds)
field.comment:
When the search bar is used, each keystroke triggers a search in Algolia. It’s really good for an instantsearch and as-you-type search experience, but it’s not good for analytics as it brings a lot of noise to the analytics. The delay defines how long the extension should wait before pushing data to GA.
Default value is 3000.

field.label: Trigger the push function before the delay on UI interaction
field.comment: If a user selects a search result even before the push was triggered (because of the delay), the push to GA might never be called. With this parameter you can trigger a data push to GA when the user interacts with a search result during the delay.

field.label: Trigger the push function after the initial search
field.comment: Sometimes your customers come directly to a search page from a link, so a search is triggered automatically without any action from the user. At the same time, the load of the page triggers standard GA code to track the page view. By this parameter you can specify if you want to trigger a data push on this kind of search scenario.

group.label: Tracked data
group.comment:
Please select what events we should track. Don't forget to save your preferences afterwards.

The Algolia extension for Magento will implement it automatically for you, no extra coding required.

group.label: View events
group.comment: View event tracking is based on default Magento behaviors.

group.label: Click events
group.comment: Event tracking is based on default Magento behaviors and components. If you are using a specific component that is not Magento native, please specify its DOM selector, so Algolia should know where what to target for this event.

field.label: Facet clicked
field.comment: This event will track when a filter has been selected from instantsearch.

group.label: Conversion events
group.comment: Conversion event tracking is based on default Magento behavior and will fire after dispatched events mentioned.

field.label: Product added to wishlist
field.comment: This conversion event fires on the dispatched event `wishlist_product_add_after`.

field.label: Product added to cart
field.comment: This conversion event fires on the dispatched event `checkout_cart_product_add_after`.

field.label: Place order
field.comment: This conversion event fires on the dispatched event `checkout_onepage_controller_success_action`.

field.label: Maximal number of elements per indexing job
field.comment: Default value is 300.

field.label: Remove Words If No Result
field.comment:
By default, Algolia performs "AND" queries between words, which can lead to no results pages when queries are too long or too detailed. To avoid this, you can select among the following options:
LastWords: when a query does not return any result, the last word will be considered as optional and the query will be automatically performed again (the process is repeated with the n-1 word, n-2 word, ... until there is results).
FirstWords: when a query does not return any result, the first word will be considered as optional and the query will be automatically performed again (the process is repeated with the second word, third word, ... until there is results).
allOptional: when a query does not return any result, all words will be optional. None: No specific processing is done when a query does not return any result.

field.label: Partial Updates
field.comment:
Do you want to use partialUpdateObjects instead of addObjects?
You should enable this option if you want to update only some attributes of your records from an external source without avoiding overriding Magento data.

field.label: Enable Customer Groups
field.comment:
Do you want to take into account customer groups and display the price of the logged-in group instead of the default price?
⚠ If you want to sort by the price attribute on the instant search results page, this option will create a replica index for each customer group, thereby multiplying the amount of records in Algolia.

field.label: Remove pub/ from image URLs
field.comment:
Do you want to replace an image URL like example.com/pub/media/image.jpg by example.com/media/image.jpg?
Activate this if your server is set to use the pub/ directory as a root directory.

field.label: Make a backend search query
field.comment:
Do you want Algolia to perform backend search queries on the search results page?
Algolia works only on the frontend and by default it us up to Magento to fetch the results for backend rendered pages. Activate this to let Algolia return results to Magento's backend rendered pages.

field.label: Search input DOM Selector
field.comment: If you don't have the top.search block, you can specify a DOM selector of your search input here to make the search work. Default value is .algolia-search-input.

field.label: Update products in changed category?
field.comment: Do you want the extension to automatically update the product index when a category is changed?

field.label: Prevent backend rendering
field.comment: ⚠ By preventing your store from backend rendering you might break your SEO and accessibility of your store by search crawlers. Please, read the documentation before you turn backend rendering off.

field.label: Allow backend rendering for User Agents
field.comment: To specify multiple User-Agents, please put one User-Agent per line.

field.label: Product numeric textfield attributes
field.comment: Choose here the textfield attributes that you don't want to be turned into numeric values (i.e. : if you don't want "00123" turned into "123")

field.label: Archive log clean limit
field.comment: (In days - default value is 30) Sets the limit when the oldest records should be cleared from the archive logs (algoliasearch_queue_archive).

group.label: Advanced - Extra Algolia indices settings
group.comment:
Here, you can specify additional Algolia indices settings which can be applied only programatically via one of Algolia API clients.

To set extra settings, please fill the right textarea with JSON where you specify the extra settings.
Example: {"exactOnSingleWordQuery":"word"}

⚠ Edit extra settings only when you're sure what you're doing. Bad settings can effect your search functionality and have a bad impact on your relevance.
